description: Use History Records collected in {Flowdometer - (2) Listener Finds Changed Records} to create Flow and Step records for the record being tracked
label: Flowdometer - (3) Listener Creates Trackers

description: Only fill this out if you are tracking a custom object. If so, put in the API name of the object
name: varTrackedCustomObjectName

elements.element: Use History Records collected in {Flowdometer - (2) Listener Finds Changed Records} to create Flow and Step records for the record being tracked

description: Only fill this out if you are tracking a custom object. If so, put in the API name of the object
name: varTrackedCustomObjectName

ruleDefinition.name: APIVersion
ruleDefinition.label: Old API version
ruleDefinition.description: Newer API components may cause older versions of Flows to start behaving incorrectly due to differences in the underlying mechanics. The Api Version has been available as an attribute on the Flow Object since API v50.0. It is recommended to limit variation between API versions and to maintain them on a regular basis.

ruleDefinition.name: CopyOf
ruleDefinition.label: Copy Of API Name
ruleDefinition.description: Having multiple elements called Copy_X_Of_Element will decrease the readability of the Flow. If you copy and paste them, make sure to update the API name of the new copy.

ruleDefinition.name: DMLStatementInLoop
ruleDefinition.label: DML statements in a loop
ruleDefinition.description: To avoid hitting Apex governor limits, we recommend grouping all of your database changes together at the end of the flow, whether those changes create, update, or delete records.

ruleDefinition.name: FlowDescription
ruleDefinition.label: Missing flow description
ruleDefinition.description: Descriptions are useful for documentation purposes. It is recommended to provide information about where it is used and what it will do.

docRefs.label: Naming your Flows is more critical than ever. By Stephen Church

ruleDefinition.name: FlowName
ruleDefinition.label: Flow Naming Convention
ruleDefinition.description: Readability of a flow is very important. Setting a naming convention for the Flow Name will improve the findability/searchability and overall consistency. It is recommended to at least provide a domain and a short description of the actions undertaken in the flow, in example Service_OrderFulfillment.

docRefs.label: Don't hard code Record Type IDs in Flow. By Stephen Church.

ruleDefinition.name: HardcodedIds
ruleDefinition.label: Hardcoded Ids
ruleDefinition.description: IDs are org-specific, so dont hard-code IDs. Instead, pass them into variables when the flow starts. You can do so, for example, by using merge fields in URL parameters or by using a Get Records element.

ruleDefinition.name: MissingFaultPath
ruleDefinition.label: Missing error handlers
ruleDefinition.description: Sometimes a flow doesnt perform an operation that you configured it to do. By default, the flow shows an error message to the user and emails the admin who created the flow. However, you can control that behavior.

ruleDefinition.name: MissingNullHandler
ruleDefinition.label: Missing null handlers
ruleDefinition.description: If a Get Records operation does not find any data it will return null. Use a decision element on the operation result variable to validate that the result is not null.

ruleDefinition.name: UnconnectedElements
ruleDefinition.label: Unconnected elements
ruleDefinition.description: Removing unconnected elements which are not being used by the Flow makes your Flow more efficient and maintainable.

ruleDefinition.name: UnusedVariables
ruleDefinition.label: Unused variables
ruleDefinition.description: Removing unconnected variables which are not being used by the Flow makes your Flow more efficient and maintainable.
